row.Text: Related post on meta.SE: [Why is the Community user listed on two brand-new sites as having been a member for 3 years and 11 months?](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/376085/why-is-the-community-user-listed-on-two-brand-new-sites-as-having-been-a-member)
@HenryWHHackv3.0 thanks for pointing that out. No solution thought.

Anyone that follows the goings-on of SE would be able to see that it launched, I imagine. Merely navigating to the newly-created site while logged into an SE account allows you to join the private beta. It seems that Jeremy continues to be interested in newly created sites and was able to join. As soon as he did, the network wide suspension kicked in and applied a suspension on this site.

One has to know that the site went up in order to "merely navigate to the newly-created site". I wonder how someone that was not informed by email could know that the site went up within just minutes.

There's an [Area 51 feed](https://area51.stackexchange.com/feeds/beta) for new beta sites that some chatrooms subscribe to. If they also visit various chatrooms that have configured their room's feeds to output new beta sites to them, they may have seen the message that a new site had launched. The feed is pretty quick to report new sites having launched. They wouldn't be able to talk in those chatrooms due to the suspension, but they'd be able to read the messages in the rooms they're in.
Can you name one chatroom that uses that feed? Feeds also take about 15 minutes on average to land in a chatroom.
I can see your MathJax perfectly fine https://i.sstatic.net/Gb7H1.png :p
@TheSimpliFire maybe it was enabled recently? I do not see it yet. Probably it needs time to pass through caches.
I do not see the equation rendered as in @thesimplifire png
@selene It turns out I had enabled https://www.math.ucla.edu/~robjohn/math/mathjax.html
Currently facing the same problem. Unable to see the latex style equation formatting. Stuff just appears as is between the $$.
could we have a feedback from the SE staff on this feature request please? @V2Blast
@JNat or someone else from SE - how do we get this enabled?

For future reference, moderators (or staff) can add the [status-review] tag to the question (as you have now) to escalate it for staff attention, per this process described on MSE: [What posts should be escalated to staff using \[status-review\], and how do I escalate them?](https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/348642/335251)
Does this issue still persist?
I was just awarded a bunch of badges...thinking y'all fixed it? It did persist up until yesterday.
I’m voting to close this question because the issue has since been resolved
@Ethan is that the normal procedure on meta, or does staff usually add a tag saying that it has been resolved?
@selene I completely forgot about the tags. A staff member shout add the [tag:status-completed] tag.
This seems much more likely than the theory presented in the comments on the question.
I don't agree. Those questions aren't necessarily supoosed to go on the main site, and we have to be clear that users should not steal other people's questions.

@NikeDattani I did not write that they all should be transferred and I wrote "**Technically** any user ... can ..." --- You can try to put a recommendation here on meta that only the original author of the question should transfer it here. I do not feel it is right to make some strictly limiting recommendation. Certainly after certain time passes no one should be frowned upon for transferring a neglected question. --- The other answer by anonymous2 is certainly more detailed. I think that one should be accepted instead of mine :)
@NikeDattani I improved my answer.
"also not seen on other SEs", There are sites on the SE network using MathJax.
True, there are other SEs with math notation enabled. Seems that the default is to disable the feature - current edit clarifies that.

Yes, it is intentional that it is disabled by default. From the page: *MathJax increases page load times drastically, so it's only supported on sites that have demonstrated a serious need for it.* --- To explain it: the main concern is load time in the web browser which is increased because of loading an running an additional JavaScript code. The answer on [There is ... no reason why ... MathJax shouldn't be enabled ...](https://meta.stackoverflow.com/a/252283/320437) shows increase of load time about 20 % on the first visit on the site. Subsequent visits will be faster.

I would rather guess that none of the Stack Exchange staff did not notice this request yet. I am guessing no-one of this community members is in contact with the Stack Exchange staff? --- I would guess that here we can expect similar amount of mathematics as on these SE sites which already have MathJax enabled: Bioinformatics, Biology, Signal Processing.

There is no reason why it should not be enabled. For this site to be useful, we need to be able to share equations. There is no way you can do quantitative Bioacoustics without equations and it is cumbersome and unnecessary to be forced to explain everything without proper math notation.
I would also vote to have equations (latex style) be enabled. If a picture says 1000 words, an equation says 1000 pictures

@pabouk-Ukrainestaystrong None of the original organizers, that I know of, are in contact with the SE staff but I'll reach out to Shannon R (the original proposer) and see if she is. Otherwise, I agree that it might take a little time for the SE staff to get these sorts of changes implemented, but keep the suggestions and discussion happening here on the Meta site!

I am not sure of exactly how one should express their support to this feature being implemented apart from upvoting this post (which of course I did). I have been a member of other SE pages that make use of MathJax (such as Physics and Signal Processing) and it is an integral part of many posts (as well as edits that many - including me - people propose on posts for readability reasons). I believe this should be enabled to each and every SE pages that have to do with any kind of scientific field/topic (such as this one).

@ZaellixA: Moderators (or staff) can add the [status-review] tag to the question (as they have now) to escalate it for staff attention, per this process described on MSE: [What posts should be escalated to staff using \[status-review\], and how do I escalate them?](https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/348642/335251) That'll create an internal ticket for the CMs, and we can triage the issue to the relevant CM subteam or other team.
Private beta runs in a special mode. I am just guessing: This could be the reason these review queues are not available? Maybe at this phase only Stack Exchange staff takes care of such tasks?
@pabouk-Ukrainestaystrong Yes private beta has its differences compare to public beta or graduated mode, but this behaviour is an unexpected one.
I only see 1 close vote and we need 5 to close a question. And since we get access to cast close votes are 15 rep most people have that perm so they cant flag questions to go into that queue.

But questions with an (at least 1) active close vote are also sent to the queue for review. (It doesn't matter if it's a close vote or flag it should be in there.) I did some personal testing and I have confirmed this.

Weird since in the help article it says
`The Close votes queue includes questions that other users have flagged as needing to be closed.`

@Ethan Also in the help center is this ["Any post which currently has an active **close vote** or a **close flag** will appear in the Close votes review queue."](https://bioacoustics.stackexchange.com/help/privileges/close-questions) I understand the confusion.
Yep, that's broken but in a different way than last time, heh. Thanks for the report! I'm looking into it.

Maybe you could post your second section ("So what can you do to help the Bioacoustics site make it to public Beta?") on Area51.meta so that it benefits to all Beta sites: [What are the criteria to go from private to public beta?](https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/32773/what-are-the-criteria-to-go-from-private-to-public-beta)

I'm planning on updating all the relevant documentation, so posting it in a question is likely not necessary (especially 'cause the relevant info is scattered around the site already). I might post an announcement when the changes are rolled out, though, if relevant ;)
Has a general invitation been sent out to bioacoustics-l mailing list? I don't think I saw one
I don't know what "bioacoustics-l mailing list" is meant to be referring to — can you clarify, @DanStowell ?
https://www.mail-archive.com/bioacoustics-l@cornell.edu/maillist.html ---- I think maybe we can do this after the site goes public?

I'm not familiarized with this mailing list, so I wouldn't be able to advise on how to proceed. As mentioned in the original question, you _should_ be inviting experts you think will participate in a way that will help this community grow into a self-sustaining one. I'm not sure if posting to a mailing list is the best way to accomplish that.

@DanStowell With only 25 questions asked at this point, it's very unlikely this site will go public. That's what this question is trying to convey - going public is not guaranteed - y'all have to show us there's interest in this subject enough to make it viable and, as of now, you're not there.
Expanding on Cat's comment [here](https://bioacoustics.meta.stackexchange.com/a/29/70).
The mailing lists are for experts, so those are appropriate for outreach.
Hi @ethan I made that edit and agree!
As this wasn't the main question I'll just put it as a comment, but I think it is also normal for the Beta stage to take a few years even.

Related: [How can you help Bioacoustics make it from Private to Public Beta?](https://bioacoustics.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/11/how-can-you-help-bioacoustics-make-it-from-private-to-public-beta)

The "beta stage" you're referring to, @selene, that can take a few years, is the _public_ beta stage, not the _private_ beta stage — and this site is currently in the latter. The private beta stage takes up to ~4 weeks, after which the site either makes it into public beta, or it doesn't and any new attempts at it will need to go through the Area 51 process from the start again.
@JNat thanks for clarifying!
I had the same frustration and just recently figured this out so thanks for asking this!
@JNat why was status-completed added?

[Stack Exchange policy](/help/promotion) is that if you are linking, referencing, etc. something with which you are affiliated, including that you are the author of the paper/book, then you **must** disclose that affiliation *in the post where you put the link and/or reference*. If you don't disclose your affiliation, then it is spam, by definition, as used on SE, which is even stated and linked in the flag dialog. That doesn't mean that situations shouldn't be handled with more nuance than red-flag nuking good content, but it does mean there **must be** disclosure (which can just be "my").

Second the acceptability. I'd even add preprints, posters and online talks into the list of acceptable references. Irrespective of whether the reference is peer-reviewed or not (we know how variable the quality can be!), ultimately it is upto the person who raised the question to go into the relevance, suitability and correctness of each answer and reference for their particular situation.
A lot of the quoted text is for StackOverflow.
@NikeDattani I do not see how it is since it doesn’t mention programming or anything related

Even if it is for SO, there are strong parallels for us as biacousticians to get inspiration from. For the basic scientists among us, replace 'book' for 'poster/preprint/paper' and voila. For those from/with companies/NGOs the terms are much more directly connected.

At this point, I wouldn't want to discourage those questions because some folks coming to the Bioacoustics site might not be familiar with SO (or might be intimidated by it as we found out in our outreach efforts) so this might be a more approachable place to ask, then if moderators do know of an identical question elsewhere, they can link to it, but maybe it can get answered here as well. Or is that totally not the right approach?

Waterproofing tick B), now I'm wondering if you have an idea what kind of effect such a covering will have on the mic characteristics (sensitivity and directionality). Sounds like worth a try nonetheless!
Thanks for this @Henry Ecker. Is it good to have some of those "borderline" questions in at this stage to provide discussion points for the community?

A big part of beta is defining what is on-topic for this site (defining scope). Personally, I think questions that are borderline (which I am defining as: questions that are clear enough to be answerable but do not appear to be directly related to bioacoustics) should be closed (and improved and reopened where possible). I was just trying to say that these questions should be closed because they do not establish their relationship to bioacoustics (missing some key details) rather than be closed simply by virtue of having been asked/answered elsewhere on the network.

There is a fine line to navigate between having a healthy meaningful site and not discouraging users... Before closing, would it be worth commenting & requesting they edit their question to show that they LOOKED on those other sites? Perhaps to help 'train' our users, we could have a canned comment we use that states that the question must relate directly to Bioacoustics & that they need to show they have not found a suitable answer on sites x, y, or z. If they do not edit, then close. If they do-- then they help all the others learn as well??? Then we can be more strict in the future?
Well...as soon as I asked a question mine went up...so I will edit my question!
Most of your questions should be covered by [this help center article](https://bioacoustics.stackexchange.com/help/whats-meta).
Yes that helps with knowing votes etc don’t matter on meta, but it says the rep points should be syncing every hour and that is definitely not the case
Thanks, Ethan, that makes sense. It seems like it does not refresh to mirror your reputation on the main site until you've actually asked a question on Meta.
It's not refreshing every hour.

I think we can eliminate the 'acoustics' part of these tags, since this site will be all about acoustics, and I might suggest simplifying the term (air instead of airborne). If someone is doing vibration in air, they might use both tags.
Maybe air, water, solid? To keep them short and simple
Sounds good to me!
Alternative suggestion for solid: perhaps 'dense' mediums? This is how I often refer to mediums such as compacted earth, wood, etc.
maybe "substrate" instead of solid. It seems to be the term used in vibratory communication ("subtrate-borne vibratory communication")
My vote is for 'underwater' or 'water' (not differentiating marine/fresh), since this is a gradient (where would the poor estuarine folks go?).
I should add that I lean towards inclusivity...Plus, we are bioacousticians afterall, aren't we?
I would also suggest we use the tag 'ID'.... which is a shorter version of "Sound-ID" suggested earlier-- but given the nature of the site, I feel that 'sound' is redundant.

I agree it would be a good thing to have, as per your question on Beta, there isn't anywhere that answers these sorts of questions. Maybe this could be the go-to site for that? How would people asking upload their sounds? Would there be an accepted platform / set of platforms people could link to?

SE makes it really easy to add photos using Imgur. I don’t know if a similar platform for sounds but can do some digging…maybe that is a feature that could be added specific for this site (perhaps should be a new question on Meta).

I support this as a type of question. I was reading up on this a litte b/c I have a few unknowns I'd like to ask for the group's help with. I believe Soundcloud or YouTube are accepted if you want to upload a sound clip.
@angie_zorka can you make an example post? There is one already I think but now I want to know what your mystery sound is :)
@selene Will do! Be warned, I have a folder of mystery sounds -- pandora's box hahaha
Do we need to get SoundCloud embedding turned on for our site? Video Production Meta's site if you paste the link, it will be rendered with an embedded player. Maybe I am still doing it wrong.
@angie_zorka, I think your Q re Embedding SoundCloud would serve as its' own question in Meta (can we do it, how to do it?)
I agree that ‘identification’ might be a better tag (more easily translated & therefore more inclusive)

In the gardening SE site, the tag is "identification" https://gardening.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/identification, while in the biology SE site, it is "species-identification" https://biology.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/species-identification

I think 'receiver' is confusing-- a receiver can also be a hydrophone. I think there is room for both hearing AND audiometry (in my ignorant opinion), as audiometry is (I think) a subtopic of hearing related to measurement of hearing (?is it?)
Can you explain or give an example? Thanks!!
@Shannon added!
One idea: do not post these types of questions until later in the Beta process, where we feel the balance leans more towards improving our success rather than reducing our chances
What about an example of an interesting sound that we do know the answer too and so someone can answer and show how that sort of question might be approached?
Great idea , and especially if it is a recent one

I don't think that we should be trying to "game the system" by avoiding questions in this way. If people are using the Beta site often enough for it to be deemed successful enough for public Beta then a small handful of questions aren't going to tilt the balance one way or the other. Also my interpretation of those metrics is that they are more of rough guidelines to aim for and not as much of a strict # requirement compared to the commitment phase. I think we should just use the site in the same way we would if it was live

@TaikiSakai I agree I don't think we need to restrict these types of questions at this point, but if we do a good example then maybe it will set the tone for what useful info is needed for folks to help with this type of question. I tried to suggest that for the current identification question and I think it looks ok. What do others think?

@TaikiSakai They were used as hard metrics, once, but that's not the way the company's doing things at the moment, I don't think. (Look at all the sites that _graduated_ without meeting those criteria!)
"NFC" is clearly redundant with "nocturnal-flight-call". Assuming NFC has no other meanings within the bioacoustics community, that's a clear case for setting up a tag synonym.
I can agree that both are not necessary! :)
I suck at tag making so apologies to my future deleters. Haha.
These are all really good points! Thank you for such a thoughtful answer. I think I'd be in favor of keeping nocturnal flight call over NFC, as abbreviations can overlap and become confusing.

When you earned the privilege, the system should've pointed you to [this help center page](https://bioacoustics.stackexchange.com/help/privileges/approve-tag-wiki-edits) too, which has some useful context.
Relevant FAQ on MSE: [What is a tag wiki? How do I write a good one?](https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/214337/335251)

Thank you for this very informative answer! I suspect that we (like the Biology site) will want to keep this option, but I really like the idea of linking users to a good how-to on how to ask good 'identify this' questions. Helpful!!!
Thank you! Those examples with extensive guidance on how to ask such questions will be really useful for us, I think.
Great question (and should my response here be a question or comment?!)
Thanks for your question! Many of us just joined the Stack world and, although there is a guideline for that, it might help new users to clarify how to use this system.
I added "do we want it" to the title of this question to hopefully encourage other users to see this question and interact with it to show interest in adding this feature!
Maybe it is too early at the beginning of beta phase? Now it is certainly good when many users get points for good questions.

Relevant FAQ on MSE: [What are "Community Wiki" posts?](https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/11740/335251) In general, there's little reason to use community-wiki status on most posts. It only really makes sense to apply it when you're dealing with something like a canonical Q&A that's intended to be openly editable by everyone – and specifically, edited often to keep it up to date. (See Mark's answer below.)

Even if a post is not made community-wiki, users without the ability to edit others' posts directly can usually suggest an edit. (The one exception I know of is on Meta sites, where users without that privilege can't edit others' posts at all – they can only edit posts they didn't write if the post has community-wiki status applied to it. This is usually done mainly for FAQs about the site/its policies, where the question and answer are meant to represent the consensus of the community rather than any one user's opinion.)
To discuss how to change a post into a wiki, in practice, see the other selene's post [here](https://bioacoustics.meta.stackexchange.com/q/100/73)

Others threads which could benefit from a wiki (because they will be kept being updated forever): [Holistic intro to Bioacoustics](https://bioacoustics.stackexchange.com/questions/121/holistic-intro-to-bioacoustics-for-newbies), [Bioacoustics in audio-art performances](https://bioacoustics.stackexchange.com/questions/751/bioacoustics-in-audio-art-performances), [What software to downsample large audio file](https://bioacoustics.stackexchange.com/questions/383/what-software-do-you-use-to-decimate-downsample-your-large-acoustic-files)

@Noil Would it help to have a meta post for each one of these questions you flagged here, so that we can tag them accordingly and sort of make a "to-do" list to have the moderators conver them? I'm happy to help tackle editing once they are converted to a CW. In that case we could also have post-specific discussion in case someone had a strong argument AGAINST converting any of the suggestions.

@selene Do you mean to add posts in this thread? Another possibility would be to flag these post for moderator's attention (built-in flag option), and then if they are flagged by several people, moderators can decide whether or not it is worth turning them into a wiki, which is maybe the standard way to do so in SE?

@Noil I was proposing a separate meta post per each main SE candidate CW question, but yes, flagging would be good too! Maybe we should ask the moderators what they prefer...I tried tagging them here but since they aren't in this thread that didn't work but maybe we can ping them on the chat.

When answers are partial, incomplete, or without references, then I think it is helpful to have canned responses from the community & moderators (us!) that help get us closer to where we want to be (a robust site with good information and without excessive sloppy answers or excessive discussion on the primary site). If an answer is partial or needs help, then we can ask them to improve. The community can vote down questions that are not good.
Perhaps for each of these situations, there should be an independent question here on Meta on how to respond-- and then we can look to other sites for suggested responses.
For what it's worth, I do not think we can bold, link, or other text modifications in a comment. Will add in a slight modification in my response above to add more explanation.

Comments can get not only buried but also deleted. Comments are not meant to be permanent on Stack Exchange. Important information from a comment should go into an answer (new or existing) or question (when the comment improves the question).
I like that approach. Will give that a go on this specific scenario and see how it goes :)
You read my mind! I was catching myself doing that the other day and thought, maybe I should use their full name and current title and put a link to their ResearchGate or LinkedIn page.
Great response. I think you are right, especially if their real name is implied by their username.

For something specific to a particular site like this issue, a request on this Meta site would actually be more appropriate. (This question is already sufficient for that.) If there's consensus from the community that this should be enabled for the site (and it's a request that is something we can do), then the site mods can escalate it to CMs/staff by adding the [status-review] tag to the Meta post... Or that's what I would recommend on a site that has mods, anyway. Since this site's in private beta and doesn't yet have mods, we'd probably suggest waiting until pro-tem mods are elected.
Thank you for the guidance! We will revisit this at Public Beta.
interesting to see that ~90% of existing non-beta sites have less than 10questions per day https://stackexchange.com/sites?view=list#questionsperday
I'm wondering about this too. I've also asked questions to which there are often multiple good answers, and I'm not sure if I should just accept one over another one when multiple answers are good.
It's expected that it will take at least a year to reach the reputation goals for Beta -- the "90 day" timeframe was abandoned long ago. Trying to push it faster will just cause problems.
I agree re: waiting a little. You can also change which answer you accept if you find a different one is a more appropriate fit.
Yay! I am assuming the text about Parity the Substrate company doesn't apply to us. Is there anything similar you are concerned about with our site?
@selene: You are correct – I assume JNat just forgot to take that part out when they copied the text over from the corresponding post on Substrate's Meta... I've edited it out now :)
V2Blast is correct, @selene — I overlooked areas of the post I thought only had boilerplate text, oops!
How many are you expecting will be elected? --- Ah, I see that the page says "3". (I would have expected a bit more)

The chat room is an interesting idea! I was checking it regularly at the start but it hasn't been used in days. Perhaps if we did set up a "how do I find a paper" question, then that answer could suggest the chat room? I've got the alerts on and don't mind for now because its quiet :)
I created a site scope for our proposal--- and this is something we need to work on for the Public Beta. I will post a separate Q here for the group to revise.
and I agree on your answer!
@Shannon Sounds good!

There are at least a couple of people here who publishes ecoacoustics studies (I will tag their name in he Shannon's Q to get some help). But I don't know for biotremology; I could advertize the SE site in the biotremology google group.
I can share within the biotremology network too, but the google group is the best place as @Noil suggests

Note that while folks can encourage others to join, they'll need to actually nominate themselves when the election starts in order to be a candidate. (In other words: While you can *informally* "nominate" others by encouraging them to run or saying they'd make a good mod, they'll need to be willing to nominate themselves in order for them to actually be considered a candidate in the election.) You might know this already, but I just wanted to clarify that. So on that note... If you want to say "these people would make good mods", you may want to edit your answer to explain why you think so :)
Ah ok, I totally missed the first part of that when reading through. Thank you for clarifying!
What about Selene ? Their active on the main site and meta.
BTW, you are talking about "non-human animal sounds", so what are "human animal sounds"?

Question: I understand 'non-human' allows us to keep out medically related human hearing+sound production questions, and the current core of the site is non-human (topic wise!) researchers. What does the community think of allowing/including non-medical related human based questions? There may be a lot to gain by inviting knowledge sharing from human audiology, noise and voice production research? (Should this be a separate question??)

I think human-related topics sit well with Biology SE, but those who study human hearing/sound are welcome to put in their advice on this site. I think we have a lot to learn from those folks, but I also think we want to keep our niche related to animals & the environment?

There is also the neuroscience SE which covers hearing (mostly human): 76 questions on "the [sensation and perception of sound information by the brain in humans and animals](https://psychology.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/hearing)"

But I don't know how much significant 76 questions is :-D. Choosing the boundaries is not easy... The best may be to have an relatively broad pitch to let the community's questions build the boundaries themselves. A vague-enough pitch but not too much haha. "Non-human animal sounds" strictly excludes humans so may not be the best, but "animal sounds" ranges in-between I think, as whether human is included or not is ambiguous.
To be more inclusive of biotremology & soundscape, we could add references to ecological sound? If someone wants to rewrite this as a different answer that includes ecological sound-- go for it!
"Sound" can sometimes be understood as not including vibration (solid acoustic), so maybe we should precise "sound (in any medium)", or use "acoustic wave" or even "mechanical wave"
@Cam Desjonqu, maybe you could help to find the best words to add ecoacoustics in the SE bioacoustics pitch?
@Dan Stowell, maybe you could help to find the best words to add ecoacoustics in the SE bioacoustics pitch?
suggest that if you want to include biotremology, you need to add substrate-borne vibration, or vibrational waves- because biotremology deals with non-compressional waves (e.g. not sound)\

I really like this-- but I would like to see something about the ecological role of sounds (or role of sounds in the ecosystem). Does research/analyse both need to be there? Or perhaps 'research related to these topics'?

@Shannon On the one hand, I want to say "research" because I really do want the site to focus on scientific questions. On the other hand, I don't want to say "research" because I don't want non-scientists to think they can't join in! ... But I do like your suggested "...research related to these topics", I think that's a good balance
Would it be appropriate to add ecosystems this way: "the impacts of sounds on animals and ecosystems"? It's not precise, but maybe it suffices

I like the sound of both of those suggestions. I wonder if this should be a new answer or different? Either way is fine.... I did realize that my earlier answer was 'locked' and I had to minor edit an answer so that I could 'unlock' my vote (and then edit it back to the original).

In the context of this SE I'm only interested in sound/vibration of NON-human species (and the effect of it) and I hope that discussion does NOT go to generic organism (which includes humans). Why? including humans opens another pandora's box.
@WMXZ I agree we should "keep humans out of it" (mostly) but I think we do that by our moderation, not by this short text
My suggestion is to stick with Dan's answer (Jul 25 at 9:03)
I like the idea of "organisms" instead of "animals"
There is less ambiguity with "organism" than with "animal". For instance, common usage and e.g. UK legal usage of "animal" does not include arthropods.
And indeed, "organism" also includes plants (e.g. some of which detect pollinator vibrations to release nectar etc..).
yes plants should be included, right? plant bioacoustics is a hot topic right now
For practical consequences of turning into Wiki, this (MSE) post is interesting: [What are "Community Wiki" posts?](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/11740/what-are-community-wiki-posts)
Agreed, and this also applies to big questions that are either lacking context, or should be broken down into multiple specific questions. But perhaps that is another topic
Since your question seems to be primarily about the post title, here's a relevant FAQ on MSE: [How do I write a good title?](https://meta.stackexchange.com/q/10647/335251)
FWIW, I will only put my name in the hat if there are not enough people. I have a list of other ways I hope to strengthen this community, but will step up if needed.
I like this. Question: should this be paired with a downvote to encourage the author to edit? Is that too harsh?
Downvote might discourage new users - too much too soon?

Is the asker noticed when someone edit their question? I tried to find this answer on meta.stackexchange, but didnot succeed. If they are noticed, maybe we don't need to comment as well about the edit?
Yes. I received a notice in my inbox when someone edited my post.
We can include this in the edit summary and it won't show up as an actual comment
Do you know if the edit summary gets forwarded on to the person when they are alerted to the edit, or is it just stored with the revisions of the question?

That's exactly what I was wondering. That seems like a lot of editing (which we wouldn't want to do long term) but because of the timing of the question with private beta, etc., I was wondering the best way to proceed.
I think the limitation of the comparison w/ the Japanese Language SE is that our site will most likely have a wider variety of questions that might be considered 'wiki-worthy'.
I think the example you outline in case one is the one I am more thinking of. But yeah, it is a slippery slope. Perhaps we can recommend un-accepting an answer?
I'm not sure how I feel about down votes, especially if the original answer has good info in it!
Adding the follow is a great idea for those of us with access to moderator tools.
if there are good info in it, of course we shouldnt downvote, but maybe just not upvote automatically in this case (if we want to have the best responses located on the top of the thread)?

The moderator (and SE staff) @V2Blast who closed it justified it by "That whole table seems to effectively be a self-answer to the question, and would probably be more appropriate as an answer than as part of the question. That said, however, this sort of question is not a good fit for the Stack Exchange Q&A format. "What are all of the things that these 3 languages are good and bad at?" is way too broad for a single Q&A, and also seems quite subjective (especially at the level of simplification being done in this post). As such, I've closed this question. "
Thanks for adding - good to have the official reason here.

I think a wiki may have been the way to and I agree that I should have specified links in the answers with some evidence. I think part of the reason this was closed is that it was too close to the classic "which programming language is best" question that is never useful. However, this was a more specific context and perhaps a community wiki is a better fit.

Periodically if I see a question that has a good answer (in some cases the OP even comments on that answer that it was great), I put a comment on the original question so that it will show in their 'inbox' and hopefully they will accept the answer.

Maybe there could be a tag that would highlight these types of questions - career-advice or something like that. That would allow those questions, but give them a specific home and maybe a specific set of guidelines.
do we NEED to have more than 3 nominations? We currently have more-- but I am wondering if there is any benefit or requirement to having >3 nominations? Thanks for your help!

@Shannon For an election with N spots available, there needs to be N+1 candidates, otherwise the nomination period will be extended so that more people can consider nominating themselves. This is just the SE policy. They want elections to be competitive (i.e. more candidates than open positions).

Your rhetorical questions "what else" e.g. stats, ADC are not helpful, in my opinion: indeed, there are stats questions for which I would advise you to use https://stats.stackexchange.com/ and ADC questions for which I would advise https://dsp.stackexchange.com/ If the question itself, and a "good" answer to your question, would not really contain anything bioacoustics-specific, then why not ask somewhere else? There's no insult or harm in doing so. S.E. is not a closed world, we can happily use those other Q&A sites, and get more+better answers!

My original response to your question was not an attempt to shut it down, though you seem to have reacted as if it was. My first response was "what makes this a bioacoustics question? Why do you feel bioacoustic deep learning would be different from other deep learning" - and these are questions I would expect you to clarify, in the wording of your question.

@DanStowell - you are right. I should not have used the word instantly as you did coment beforehand. I have edited the answer to reflect that. I still think that these types of question are applicable to bioacoustics because it is cross disciplinary and the bioacoustics context in both the question and answers can be more valuable than a stack exchange which is more immediately focussed on the topic.

@DanStowell. I have edited the question to add context. I feel this has been a useful exercise. I think the main issue here was that this type of question is still (in my opinion at least) appropriate but it was not explained in the question SPECIFICALLY WHY it was appropriate. That's a lesson for me and I think the community as a whole and should be taken forward as we moderate the site.

I like Noil's phrasing of "If the question is borderline" here, and Noil's way of expressing the rule number 2. It's "borderline relevant" questions that are the issue we need to resolve. @Shannon this is exactly why I posted a comment on the OP's question, to give a chance to edit it and clarify the relevance. I think Stack Exchange's built-in mechanisms already allow a "grace period" for this kind of thing, since it requires multiple moderators to vote to close a question - it's almost never going to happen instantly, for good-faith questions such as the OP's.
Yes, I think that a combination of guidelines as Shannon has suggested along with the mechanisms Stack Exchange provides should provide a good framework for us to moderate the site.
Well done, these 2 questions (and associated answers) would be very helpful as references in the future
Agreed, I think these guidelines are definitely needed and means we have a framework to solve disagreement.

This discussion about posting figures to twitter might be interesting to those interested in this question...although its specific to your OWN figures: https://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/188239/am-i-allowed-to-post-screenshots-of-tables-figures-of-my-paper-on-twitter

I agree with what you say as an author, Selene. One comment, though: Stack Exchange is not an educational institution nor a charity, it's a profit-making business. Thus, for example, it would probably be inappropriate to use images on SE if they are published under a Creative Commons "Non-commercial" licence ... even though the user who posted it is not making a profit! Most academic papers would not have this problem though.

That's really interesting distinction - thanks for pointing it out @DanStowell. So you are saying most academic papers would not have this problem - meaning they wouldn't have an issue with being posted on SE?
Yes, that's right
See this relevant Help Center page (as well as the blog post it links to): [Can I answer my own question?](https://bioacoustics.stackexchange.com/help/self-answer)

Yes, you understood exactly :) And appreciate your thoughts on it. Like you said I don't want to necessarily add questions just in case, but at this early stage I see some value in having it as an example question (of what kind of questions are good to ask here) since we are still sort of getting going. But I don't want to just take up space if it isn't actually useful!!

In particular, in addition to making sure that the question is actually on-topic/allowed here and a good fit for the Stack Exchange format – I think it's important to ensure that it'd actually be a "real question" that's relevant to the userbase here (e.g. a frequently asked question, or something that's likely to come up regardless). Basically, ensure that it'd be a good question and answer even if you weren't posting an already-answered question from elsewhere. (And don't plagiarize others' writing, of course.)

I agree on adding a link to the GitHub discussion. I have not posted the question because I decided it perhaps would not be relevant to the larger community. It’s a software specific error - just have to make sure the right modules are installed - so more like a bug almost and maybe not appropriate here.
The lack of transparency is what is causing the confusion and frustration (not just the suspensions themselves). What is going on?

@Chloe I very much disagree with your complaint about “lack of transparency”. There’s clear communication that a) there have been irregularities, b) these are under investigation, c) further information is promised as soon as possible. I don’t think going into detail or even naming people would be of any benefit. Transparency is good and important, but must still protect the privacy rights of those who may have been involved (-> under investigation), possibly in a misguided attempt to foster the proposal.

Not all details should be made public, especially if more information may hurt someone disproportionately. There will be (in fact, already are) consequences for individuals involved, and while I can understand that you and others would like to have more details to understand better, what’s going on, please let the folks at CM do their job for now, and be patient until there is reliable information available and the necessary decisions are made.

I say that because several colleagues have said that they are confused why their accounts were suspended when they were barely active on it in the first place. They have read your email, and understand what unethical voting entails, and they do not think they have violated any of these.

(1) JNat's post explicitly says that they have to "undertake a deeper investigation of the extent of these irregularities" before deciding what's going to happen. I think we better let them do that and not expect answers that they're not yet ready to provide, while they're still investigating the extent of the damage. (2) The election has been cancelled, so I would not think that there will be a "result".

Regarding 1: I can only speculate here, but among the main reasons for the entire Area 51 process is to avoid the work and disappointment of launching (and shutting down) a site that has not gathered a sufficiently big and active community or never will. In that respect, almost all the potential damage has already been done, except that from shutting down the site. Sending the site back to Area 51 would not improve things – on the contrary, it would dismantle whatever community you have. Thus, from SE’s perspective it makes sense to wait and see whether the site works out.
Nike's comment is correct on both counts, and pretty much what I would've responded with.
Considering at this point in time they're still planning on having a new election later down the road, I see no problem with trying to engage more people. For now.

(A) I would suggest not to read too much into the Area51 statistics and "site's progress" or "Needs Work", even though JNat gave you a link to the Area51 page. Those progress indicators are almost a decade out of date. Sites no longer need 10 questions/day to graduate, and Bioacoustics **is not doing poorly in terms of number of participants**. You can simply look at other new sites and their number of users as a function of time on the Waybackmachine. (B) Considering that it seems that the site might get shut down, I'd be hesitant to invite people as it could be bad for your reputation.

Minor clarification note: closing down the site is _not_ the desired outcome for the Community Management Team, and we still plan to hold a moderator election — the success of which might dictate the site's future. As such, while we can't _guarantee_ that the site will be successful at this point, we also don't have any issues with inviting more users at this point.
Totally agree, @Carly. 100% behind this. We have little transparency and a strong, clever, and giving community. All of this drama is such a confusing distraction.

@NikeDattani that might 'seem' humorous - but that's ... a rather serious accusation. I'd note this post was linked on main meta, and its a much more honest and direct response than we'd get. The community team has a stake in the network's constituent sites succeeding, as much as us random SE denizens.
Right now no one from the Bioacoustics can vote or post because of their accounts being suspended....there would be dozens more upvotes. Convenient, I agree.

*A warning could be far more efficient than a direct suspension, which will discourage many of us.* – As a moderator of one of the affected sites, I would like to comment on this: As early as April, we noticed problematic coordinated activities from a dozen people (who turned out to be Bioacoustics supporters). They all received warnings/suspensions or other clear signals such as post deletions, some of them twice. Naturally, we could only warn those whom we knew to be involved, but plenty of people were warned and had ample time to share their experience.
Not everyone received a warning before their suspension, I've talked to some people who did not.

Yep, I was suspended for "activities not on this site", with no warning. My last SE action outside of this forum was a single vote on march 28, and an answer on Aug 10, 2021. Peculiar to have that as grounds for suspension. Seems someone at SE just presses "ctrl+a" and then hit "suspend".

@Rasmus that is super frustrating and it seems like you may be a good candidate to appeal, if you are willing to go through that process - [this post](https://bioacoustics.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/173/deferral-of-inaugural-election-and-next-steps-for-the-bioacoustics-community) has a link to the "Contact Us" form where you can appeal

"Not a punishment" You have caused a lot of damage and mistrust in this community with these actions. Several colleagues have deleted accounts and more will undoubtedly follow if you carry on with your policy for banning folk from the moderator elections. As what you accuse us of happened before this site was even created and has not happened since, this is by definition a punishment, because it does nothing but cause harm to this site. This was not the way to treat this community.

As mentioned in the messages and in the post, the aim of our actions was not to discourage further participation — we understand our actions cause frustration, and although they were not an easy decision to come to, they were the ones the circumstances and evidence led us to take.

@JamieMacaulay You're correct that it hasn't happened _since_ the site launched, but these votes occurred weeks before the suspensions were issued, and had a negative impact on many sites across the network. That negative impact does not evaporate just because the site ultimately launched and the impetus to vote illegitimately disappeared. So our response is ultimately protective of the network as a whole. Suspensions are often issued to ask users to step back for a bit and re-evaluate _how_ they engage with the site, particularly when it is causing problems network-wide.

Sure, I get it. We broke the rules so you have to make an example of us. It’s the way you went about it, without warning, without trying to work with the community for an explanation (that has now been provided). Cutting out almost all the moderators in the election too. I just can’t see a justification for cost/benefit of that approach but hey, I’m also not running a giant q&a website. Fingers crossed the site moves on from all this.

@JamieMacaulay I think that is an unfair characterization. The CMs very much want this site to succeed. I understand the sentiment that wants to attribute a malicious motive to the suspensions, but I think nothing is further from the truth. StackExchange could freely delete this site or any accounts if they wanted you to leave. They acted in response to a very large voting network *without which this site might not exist*, yet they keep staff resources supporting this site. Suspensions without warning are rare here; that indicates the severity of the offense, not the callousness of staff.

Fraudulent voting broke the step where a proposal is supposed to backed by users with familiarity with how SE works, by asking or answering questions around the network. Instead, a bunch of new people brought to SE by this proposal had their first experience gaining reputation through fraudulent voting. This was likely a confusing arrival to other sites on the network, where users had their reputation gains reversed or content deleted for fraud.

I do not understand an argument that because candidates for moderator were involved, somehow SE should have taken a lighter approach. Moderators are trusted with private user data and with a lot of responsibility in setting the direction of a site. They are often expected to make decisions specifically when a clear written guideline is not available. As JNat points out, there are many potential candidates in this community that were not suspended.

@BryanKrause "*I understand the sentiment that wants to attribute a malicious motive to the suspensions*" I have not read this anywhere. This bumbled situation arose because the investigation into the fraudulent votes began *during* the election process. At least that is my impression. If the investigation had already been in process *before* the election began nobody among the staff would have allowed the nomination phase to go underway.

The investigation and the suspensions should have concluded *before* 5 users volunteered. It didn't happen because someone at SE finally woke up to the fact that several mods across the network had informed the team, *months earlier*, that something was not quite right with number of votes being cast in their sites. Community managers need to be updated on a regular basis, moderators across the network need to insist that the team responds sooner not later to any concerns raised.

The breakdown of communication between sites that are outside the big five–Stack Overflow, SuperUser, Unix & Linux, Ask Ubuntu, and Mathematics, and the team of CMs is nothing new. There are too many sites and too few CMs, and CMs who rarely if ever participate on the smaller meta sites. They probably don't have time, but it means that when something does happen, users on smaller sites will view them as uncaring strangers.

But the fact remains that there was *no warning* to the suspended (me one of them). With no examples given, and no warnings when supposedly breaking rules, it leaves us no way to learn what was done wrong.
I note the sentence: "To clarify: the problematic votes were not cast on this site, but rather on other sites on the Stack Exchange network." To my best knowledge my only activity on SE was *on this site* during this period (since Aug 10 2021), so being suspended because of activity not on this site seems puzzling, if not down-right a lie.

@Rasmus From this post: "What is abnormal and problematic, however, is to coordinate handing out votes with the explicit intention of meeting reputation-based privilege thresholds, in an attempt to aid the proposal’s progression through the Area 51 stages".

@Rasmus From the mod message posted in the question here: "Voting repeatedly for a user by discovering posts through their profile. ... Voting for posts you are directly linked to > elsewhere (e.g., in Slack or by email) ...
Deliberately voting in order to circumvent Stack Exchange system restrictions. For example, voting for a user’s posts only so that the user gains the privilege to comment. ...
Creating additional accounts (“sockpuppets”) to upvote one’s own posts. ...
Actively soliciting votes that do any of the above."

Since this whole thing was about votes occurring in order to boost this Area51 proposal prior to it [reaching Beta](https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/32767/congratulations-to-bioacoustics-on-completing-the-commitment-phase), the offending activity certainly occurred before the narrow recent window you're talking about.

@BryanKrause Again, I have not participated in any of those activities. Pre the bioacoustics beta my last activity was last summer, but they still suspended me (and others I belive). Hence, the point stands, we were suspended with no warning for not having done anything (I've been on SE for ~6 years with no suspensions).

@Rasmus You can possibly reply to the message and ask for clarification, though the staff isn't going to discuss your case publicly here per policy and as JNat already mentioned they don't typically point to specific votes. As they've described, this wasn't an automated or capricious action but something carefully studied where patterns emerged. Suspensions only went to accounts with the most evidence, others with lesser involvement were only warned.

@Rasmus as an outsider without knowing any details and reasons, I'd assume the suspension is related to the [-200 rep voting correction on your SO profile](https://stackoverflow.com/users/7409197/rasmus?tab=reputation). Whether it's related to this case or not, who knows but the staff.
@AndrewT. I saw that too and that makes sense, except Rasmus only received 3 upvotes (30 rep points) since the start of the year/when this proposal was in the commitment phase.

@AndrewT. that -200 was because of my suspension (that's the reason given on my account) and thus not the cause of it. Also this is not because of my actions, but because others have voted on my contributions. See: https://stackoverflow.com/help/serial-voting-reversed

@Rasmus Based *entirely* on public information: The -200 voting corrected reversal on your SO account on 2022-08-26 *had nothing to do with your suspension for this issue*. The suspensions for the issues here were applied prior to 2022-08-19 (this question's date). Your reversal was 7+ days later. Your voting correction was for serial voting *to* your account in 2018 (only possibility) by at least 5 other users. >= 5 accounts is known because there were 5 sets of serial votes all on 4 posts. 5 votes on each of 4 posts requires >= 5 users, which tracks as 5 votes * 4 posts * 10 rep = 200 rep.

@Rasmus You appear to have misunderstood [the page you linked to](//stackoverflow.com/help/serial-voting-reversed). Users are *not* suspended for nor at fault for being the *target* of serial voting, unless they participated in getting the votes (e.g. created sockpuppet accounts to upvote their own posts). You've mentioned one suspension for the reason described in the question here, which was *not* because of that voting correction/reversal. Presuming you have no other, more recent suspension or moderator message, then I'd assume you were merely the target of the voting and without fault.
@Makyen thanks for the correction, but this leaves me even more confused in regards to the suspension.

Rasmus - I've heard many stories like this too from colleagues. Although some of us are guilty of up-voting folk in the community, many were not. I also cannot get over the way this was handled and the needless damage that was caused - I clearly did not understand SE's approach to these sites and have deleted my account as I do not wish to participate further - except that I need approval to do so (there is definitely a bit of irony there) @JNat I would be grateful if you could help delete my account (JamieMacaulay) - it's been 5 days now since I requested it?

@Rasmus `To my best knowledge my only activity on SE was on this site during this period (since Aug 10 2021), so being suspended because of activity not on this site seems puzzling` If your activity was this limited, it's possible your suspension was inappropriate especially if you received no prior warning. Staff *do* make mistakes, so it's worth spending some time composing an email and explaining in detail (include links etc.) why you think an error was committed when your account was suspended. https://bioacoustics.meta.stackexchange.com/contact
@Rasmus if you do appeal, please let is know if it is successful (if you are comfortable with that) here or over on that chat
Hi, I have appealed and I'm waiting for a response. Happy to share results of the appeal (unless asked not to by moderators)

(1/2) From SE: "... we included some data from the 2018 attempt to launch the Bioacoustics proposal, where similar targeted voting occurred. [...] there haven’t been any targeted votes for your account since that proposal. However, because the voting that took place in 2018 passed the threshold against which we evaluated suspensions for the current proposal, your account was included in this group of suspensions due to the votes from 2018. Additionally, those votes elevated your account over the reputation requirement needed for the current proposal to advance past the Commitment phase."

(2/2) No concrete examples were given to me, and as far as I can see from my past activities, I had no activities in 2018, nor have I ever received a warning. Maybe area 51 activity is not shown, but regardless, I have asked them to provide more details, as I do not remember engaging in "targeted" voting at any time (it's 5 years ago!).

@Rasmus thanks for sharing. It seems to me like you may have been the recipient of targeted voting but you did not yourself do that or break that part of the code of conduct (an innocent bystander of sorts). I was part of the proposal in 2018 but it was much less organized in that first attempt so I don't remember any sort of targeted voting efforts (nor do I remember you from it or know you outside of SE, if that makes you feel any better!)

Their reply to me asking for clarification and lack of warning: "Our investigation found that the actions in question did not fit the definition of organic voting but were systematic in nature, and therefore were deemed as targeted."

What a welcoming warm invitation for users to nominate themselves to moderate a site that appears to be doomed, thanks to the mishandling of this situation, users might not have the same enthusiasm as they did 10 days ago. A sensible measure would have been to wait at least a month, regain the trust of the community and give yourselves the time to carefully evaluate each user affected by the suspension, and allow each user the possibility for them to *defend* themselves. No. Instead the ship must sail even if the crew is half absent and many its officers are in jail.

thanks @Mari-LouA, indeed we (70 users according to [SE](https://bioacoustics.meta.stackexchange.com/a/148/73)) have not been able to respond yet as the 7-day suspensions have just been ending now. This includes: 4 out of 5 candidates of the cancelled moderator election; 5 out of 6 editors; most of the active users since the site activity has dropped from ~5 to 0.3 questions a week during the 7-day suspensions. This is a somehow strange practice! As far I'm concerned, I got no warning before the suspension.
I've talked to many folks who did not receive any warnings before their suspensions.
Interesting. How is a "Daily actors" defined?
@Noil Any user who did one of the following on that day: Comment, vote, flag/close vote, post, review, or edit. (Other actions don't count as activity for the purposes of this graph.)
Before declaring the patient is alive and well, I would wait to see how many of the 70 suspended users return to regular activity.

Hi Shannon, thank you sincerely for this post. We'd love to work with you all in order to make this election successful, and we understand that the timeline may be too short if your intent is to rally the community. With this in mind, we'd like to propose that we defer the election until **the community** indicates that you all feel _ready_ for an election. Once that happens then we can schedule it for a date that's as early as possible. However, the latest date we can start the election is Monday, November 7th.

If this sounds good to you, **please split the request for an election deferral off into its own post**, so the community has better visibility and a chance to discuss the issue on-site / express approval. (It seems like you've had this conversation elsewhere, which is good, though there needs to be a conversation on Bioacoustics Meta to help build assent here and make sure all members have a voice. We would also like to be able to participate in the conversation, as well.)

If the community agrees, we can commit _now_ to a deferral until the community indicates readiness (or until Nov 7th, whichever is sooner). This will both allow time for users to request internal reviews of their suspensions as needed, and allow time for you all to coordinate about a path forward. Please let me know if there are questions we can answer, or further ways we can help.

@Slate This sounds good to me- and I will post a question for others to vote on. Yes, a small group of us retain communications offline, but our preference is to shift all conversations here and use voting & comments to understand the views of our greater community. My post will likely be imperfect and require editing-- warning and thanks in advance for help editing!

No problem at all - looking forward to it! (Edit: for posterity, Shannon's post [is now live here](https://bioacoustics.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/165/request-to-defer-election-of-bioacoustics-site-moderators).)

So will people who got suspended be allowed to nominate themselves as moderators (like the original moderator nominees)? I am not seeing a clear answer to that question. Would they have to win an appeal in order to run again?
I'd also like to encourage folks to leave answers sharing your reasoning, and how you think the time would help. Voting is important, but reasoning things through in writing is always critical, too!

As a sidenote, this is just a best-practice I've found from years as a user and moderator, but... In general, when trying to establish community consensus, I'd suggest posting the question itself in the form of a question, and then using answers to recommend what should be done. (There can be multiple answers presenting different reasoning for the same course of action, of course.) I suggest this because voting on the question post can affect the visibility of the post on the meta site's front page.
@V2Blast Also because reputation gates voting up and down differently, and more people can vote up than can vote down.

Also true. [Jon Ericson's answer to this MSE question about building consensus](https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/177657/335251) has some great recommendations on how to construct meta questions to establish a consensus. ...Anyway, I hope y'all find that helpful. :)

I do see one disadvantage with this: this increases the amount of time the Stack Exchange team has to moderate the site, as they have to moderate for the period between site creation and it getting its first moderators. I do have some alternative options which I'll propose in answers.

@gparyani - I know we're all appreciative of your desire to minimize the time that staff invests here (sincerely), and I will admit that this site has certainly been the focus of a disproportionate number of staff hours these last couple of weeks, but luckily, thats' not a metric we track. If my team invests additional hours to get the site off to a positive course correction, I'm willing to swallow those hours as a necessary part of community building. So yes, please, keep it in mind, but know that we're not sweating the hours.
Should the status complete tag be added to this since the election was delayed?
@Ethan- the status complete tag is typically used for feature requests, and indicates when theyre completed. (There's a whole set of "status" tags for use with feature requests or bugs).

I greatly appreciate your ideas based on what is clearly a long history with SE! But given the events of the past week, many in our community feel even more strongly that we should elect our moderators. The one benefit from this approach that would be helpful to capture are the characteristics that experienced moderators would hone in on to identify successful community moderators (hmmm… a new Meta Q?)

There are 2 main reasons why we moved away from appointing folks in the direction of hosting elections: one of them Shannon identified in the comment above, and has to do with putting it in the hands of the community to chose their moderation team; the other reason is that the old process was way more time consuming for the CM team. You point out that the election system relies on hoping folks nominate, but the old system still relies on folks accepting the position once we offer it to them — and many times, folks wouldn't, and we'd be back at square one, making it a much lengthier process.
It’s not unusual that the community nudges what they consider good candidates to self-nominate. That’s similar to directly nominating someone (old process), but without the issues JNat mentioned.

@JNat First, if few enough people nominate that the nominees win the election by default, then the mod team isn't within the community's hands. The old system wasn't completely out of the community's hands, though: the team would consider votes on the answers when deciding.

You also mention time taken by staff, but back when the old process was in effect there were way more beta launches at a time and yet the team was still willing to go through the longer process. Now that the rate of new betas has gone down by an order of magnitude, and there are more CMs than years ago to split the work, why is time taken by the CMs more of a concern? As well, having to investigate misconduct on the part of a moderator who isn't fit for the role also takes up time, and given that pro-tem elections often result in such mods that time could add up to the same as the old way.

Finally, you imply that almost every mod who wouldn't nominate themselves but gets nominated by another user would decline the position. I argue here that that's not the case, by pointing out that such users are likely to change their mind and clear out any misgivings once someone points out in public that they're suited for the role, they're likelier to accept.

Your comment also doesn't cover the second reason I point out here, the reputation requirement. Also, in addition to the two reasons I mention here which are specifically relevant to this site, I mention some more reasons in a [chat conversation](//chat.meta.stackexchange.com/transcript/message/9136362). One of those is the ability for the team to vet the candidates.

I understand the thought process surrounding the impostor syndrome bit, @gparyani. From personal experience, though, many times I'd reach out to users to assess their willingness to take on the role, I was met with absolute silence (especially if they were nominated by someone else). So I'm not talking about declining the position, but rather about the fact that a CM would compile a list of candidates, reach out to an initial batch of 3, wait a week for a response, and then if the response was negative or absent, go back to step one — that is a lot of time spent on this.
Or, perhaps a ‘mentor’ moderator to help get moderators up to speed (if our moderators are much less experienced)

@Shannon, I've been thinking about mentorship programs for mods for some time. While we're nowhere near ready to kick such a program off, it's on my radar screen, for sure. Until such time as we do launch a program like that, our temporary solution. is to make members of my team available to your site mods for advice. We check in with all mod teams regularly and we could certainly increase frequency of that here, if we feel its needed, though I think that would depend on who nominates and is elected.

@Philippe I guess you could find a few potential volunteers for such a mentoring program within the more experienced mods as well. I’d certainly think about it, teaching new mods the ropes and paying forward the guidance I got when I started. And of course there’s always the TL for cross-site counseling.

@Stephie, yeah, my experience at SE so far indicates that there are more than a few mods who are extremely generous with their time and would be happy to help out new mods. I don't think it needs to be a time-intensive process, but someone willing to throw in a few hours to help new mods could make all the difference. I need to do a lot more thinking about how to make it work, but I am fond of the idea.

There's an SE-wide rule that anyone who was suspended on any site on the network in the year preceding an election is not allowed to run in the election, unless the suspension was in error or was successfully appealed. So yes, they would have to successfully appeal the suspension in order to win.

Moderators have access to a lot of personal and private information of users (possibly very critical when a site is closely linked to a professional community). They're also responsible for guiding the community according to SE standards. If users have been suspended for breaching trust on other sites on the network by not understanding core tenets of SE (like voting for content rather than users), perhaps it should be seen whether others are able to step up. If the site is successful, it will certainly have additional election periods in the future as every site does.

In the meantime, most moderation should really be done by the community - close votes, edits, flags, helpful comments, meta participation, up and down votes. Most diamond moderator work is in handling the occasional edge cases and gray areas.
Do the CMs or other mods have any suggestions for how to connect with/encourage potential mods?

I mentioned [here](https://bioacoustics.meta.stackexchange.com/q/84/70) what are some of the traits CMs generally looked for when considering appointing users as mods. So if you know users on the site that check all/most of those boxes, just talking to them about their interest in the position is the best way to go — chat is a good solution. Since ideally mods are already involved in the community, doing any external outreach doesn't seem like the best solution here. And, obviously, ideally we also don't pester users about the position, nor try to peer pressure them into nominating.
Has there been any update on when we want elections to happen?

Thanks and I think you would be great...but completely understand your time concern. Over on the chat are several moderators from other SE sites who are kindly sharing their knowledge and experience and they might be able to give you some feedback on what the realistic time commitment is

[OP message](https://chat.stackexchange.com/transcript/message/61896525#61896525). On Stack Apps, a very low traffic site, I have to search for things to moderate. Now my fellow mod is Glorfindel so he takes most of the flags so I usually end-up nuking spam profiles, editing wiki's, re-tagging and some occasional reviewing in the 30 minutes I spend per day for moderation duty. I doubt with a crew of 3 you would have to spend a full 30 minutes each day to keep things under control...
They shared some more data about moderating in the chat room. I would recommend joining and ask any more questions there

I was a moderator during my PhD, it was not an appreciable tax on my time. It's impossible to be PhD productive at a high level 24/7, so you'll take breaks either way, I'd rather be on SE than Facebook. I now mod on 4 sites, all small (though more activity than here). The amount of time I spend on moderator tasks in a week across all those sites is less time than I spend on one high quality answer. I spend far more time doing other types of curation that is accessible to everyone. Occasionally, a particular troll or network of cross-voting accounts will take a bit more time.

While it's a bit of a weird situation since so many of you know each other outside this site, and I don't know that there is a particular rule against using public information to ID deleted users, generally I think it's not good taste to do so. I think most of us realize that nothing is ever truly "deleted" from the internet, of course, but I think it's best to respect a user's privacy to not have their name on their account any more.

@BryanKrause I agree, that's why i used the initials "JM" and not his full former user name. Did you think that "JM" was his full user name or do you mean that i even shouldnt use the initials to make it more anonymous?

Ah, I see - no, I did not think JM was the full user name, but it *was* enough for me to guess the specific user from my limited interaction here. I had assumed you were using it as a term of familiarity that people would typically know that person by (e.g., maybe it was their name in some other off-site channel) and didn't realize that you had used the initials to try to not fully reveal the person.

answers can be updated over time as well to address slight modifications-- but if a question is really subject to what is going on at one point in time-- that doesn't fit as well into this Q&A type standard.
I think the good answers are more reflective of how our community works (we like to help!), rather than the appropriateness of question for the stack exchange platform.
I’ll update the question to follow how you clarified because yes…outreach could mean a lot of things! There are already some other questions on here about k12 resources etc.
Is networking a better category label?
Yes! Networking is more specific-- and I think it is helpful to focus on specific types of questions. If you edit yours, I'll edit mine to reflect that change
I agree! And like how Shannon added it I her suggested text above!
Wow I totally missed that Shannon had already written that into the language (*face palm*) lol. Thanks for pointing out!
Haha I’m glad we are just all thinking alike :)!
